summary: I owe it to myself
title: I owe it to myself
description:
by creepychan025

“We we’re going straight to the Eastwatched-by-the-sea and meet up with Tormund.” Ser Davos informed the King of brooding. “I already sent a raven. It should arrive days before us. You said he would be willing to help.”

“No.” Jon said making the frown in Davos face deepened. “We’re stopping by at the Winterfell shortly before going to the Eastwatched-by-the-sea.”

“Your grace–”

“This is a suicide mission, you said so yourself, then its all the more reason I need to go to Winterfell.” Jon said with conviction. “I need to see Bran and Arya. I owe it to myself.”

A FIX IT. Because Jon’s reaction in the show is such a shame.

Words: 2115, Chapters: ½, Language: English

Series: Part 2 of This love left a permanent mark

  • Fandoms: Game of Thrones (TV)
  • Rating: General Audiences
  • Warnings: Creator Chose Not To Use Archive Warnings, No Archive Warnings Apply
  • Categories: F/M
  • Characters: Jon Snow, Arya Stark, Sansa Stark, Davos Seaworth, Bran Stark, Daenerys Targaryen, Varys (ASoIaF), Tormund Giantsbane
  • Relationships: Jon Snow/Arya Stark, Jon Snow & Arya Stark
  • Additional Tags: Not Incest, implied tho?, Reunion, FIx It, little angst, If You Squint - Freeform, idk what it is but i love jonrya so

summary: It's funny that so many people cannot accept pol!jon because they think he's 100% honorable like Ned was, when Ned was perfectly...
question: It's funny that so many people cannot accept pol!jon because they think he's 100% honorable like Ned was, when Ned was perfectly able to lie when he felt it was needed but also Kit himself said that when Jon was resurrected "a little bit of bad (had) entered him, a little bit of evil". Do you think the whole 'being less when resurrected' thing is going to be relevant in s8?
answer:
“I do think that if you’re bringing a character back, that a character has gone through death, that’s a transformative experience.”

“[…] then [Gandalf] comes back as Gandalf the White, and if anything he’s sort of improved. I never liked Gandalf the White as much as Gandalf the Grey, and I never liked him coming back. I think it would have been an even stronger story if Tolkien had left him dead.”

“My characters who come back from death are worse for wear. In some ways, they’re not even the same characters anymore. The body may be moving, but some aspect of the spirit is changed or transformed, and they’ve lost something.”

“Each time [Dondarrion] is revived he loses a little more of himself. He was sent on a mission before his first death. He was sent on a mission to do something, and it’s like, that’s what he’s clinging to. He’s forgetting other things, he’s forgetting who he is, or where he lived. He’s forgotten the woman who he was once supposed to marry. Bits of his humanity are lost every time he comes back from death; he remembers that mission. His flesh is falling away from him, but this one thing, this purpose that he had is part of what’s animating him and bringing him back to death. I think you see echoes of that with some of the other characters who have come back from death.”

George R.R. Martin’s thoughts on resurrection

Looking at GRRM’s thoughts on and feelings about resurrection in fiction, it’s safe to say Jon will be different in the books. He died trying to protect a sister, which could mean he’ll be adamant in protecting his family once he returns. That it’s the mission he remembers even if he loses bits of himself. And looking at the prologue of A Dance with Dragons, we might’ve been given another hint about his resurrected self.

In the prologue, Varamyr (a wildling warg) talks about how if you warg into a wolf, you become part of the wolf and it becomes part of you. He also mentions Jon and his strong but untrained warging abilities and ends up warging into a wolf before dying. This has lead many to theorize that book!jon wargs into Ghost before dying and will stay in the direwolf’s body until resurrected and therefore come back with something of the wolf within him.

That being said, while this most definitely will be a factor in the books, I doubt any of this will actually be explained or acknowledged in the show universe. I do think it’ll inform Jon’s characterization and arc, though. Probably by making him choose family–the pack–above anything else and being more wild and ruthless when it comes to protecting the people he loves, as we’ve already seen when he pummeled Ramsay and throttled Littlefinger.

Kit even pointed this out regarding his attempt to beat Ramsay to death with his fists before Sansa showed up and pulled him out of his frenzy:

“What I loved about this is that you actually see Jon lose any of his goodness for a minute. He just turns into a monster, punching anything. He could punch the ground. He goes mad.” (Kit’s commentary to Battle of the Bastards)

And what might this mean for s8?

Jon knows nothing awaits you after death. He knows the only thing that counts is this one life and what they do with it. It will make it even more important to him to make sure his family is safe for as long as possible. This will lead to him making some tough decisions where he needs to leave his naïvité behind and let in some his ruthlessness. Because while Ned lied when needed, he did put his trust in the wrong people. Robb trusted the wrong people too. And Jon trusted Tyrion when he shouldn’t have. He’s is not looking to repeat this mistake.

In the final season, the pack will be together again and they’ll trust each other, rely on each other, and fight tooth and nail to protect each other. No matter the odds, no matter what it takes. Because when the game is rigged, when all your opponents are playing dirty, you can’t keep stubbornly playing by the rules and hope for the best. That’s how you end up dead.

Thanks for the ask!

blog.name: maisiestyle
blog.title: Maisie Williams | Arya Stark | Styles & Musings

summary:
Great recap interview by Maisie Williams of Arya’s journey! Some nice hints for the future of her story in Season 8.  
Maisie...
caption:
Great recap interview by Maisie Williams of Arya’s journey! Some nice hints for the future of her story in Season 8.

Maisie says, after LF’s death, the show wants to make a conscious decision to show Arya has changed in her final scene of S7 with Sansa. Which goes along nicely with Maisie’s recent comments about seeing a lighter more fun side to Arya in S8. Maisie also made it very clear that she got to do everything she wanted for Arya in S8 which makes what she has said (in an interview after reading the S8 scripts) of what she wants for Arya very enlightening:

Do you have ideas about how you’d like Arya’s journey to end?

Maisie: I’ve always said I wanted her to find peace. The things that have been driving her through her story have been very bitter and twisted and aggressive. I would love for Arya to find her true self again and let go of this anger and revenge that’s accompanied her on this journey. I’d love for her to be happy.

At CCXP in Brazil last week, she also said this:

The actors were forbidden in the interview to talk about the series’ eighth season, but Maisie also gave clues to Arya’s future. “Back to Winterfell was amazing, it was her focus throughout the show,” she says. “In this new season she has completely different goals, which she has never had before,” she says.
Interesting.

tags: or did we already put this together and i'm just slow lol
summary: one thing that stuck out to me in Kit’s interview where he recaps Jon Snow’s plot with Dany is when he says “she needs him [...]...
body:
one thing that stuck out to me in Kit’s interview where he recaps Jon Snow’s plot with Dany is when he says “she needs him […] to be her commander rather than a king.”

commander seems an interesting choice since i don’t recall any of them using that word in season 7 (for Jon, anyway), so i wonder if this is the capacity in which he will be serving her at the start of season 8, commander of her army. he’s her Warden of the North, of course, but i have been wondering if he would serve any other role as well, such as adviser or whatnot. she clearly values his advice and experience, and he is the best military man they have at the moment, so it makes sense.

reblog.comment:

trail.content:

summary: Sansa believes that Theon killed Bran and Rickon and betrayed her older brother Robb and she confronts him for it. That [Theon...
body:
Sansa believes that Theon killed Bran and Rickon and betrayed her older brother Robb and she confronts him for it.

That [Theon telling her he didn’t kill Bran and Rickon and that they are probably alive] is the hope that Sansa needs, that drives her to want to get out of there, to want to survives, and Theon wants to help her.

The moment that Sansa sees Jon again is the first moment of real happiness that Sansa’s probably had on the Show.  Everything that she’s been fighting to survive for is to see her family again and to see Jon, there is just such a sense of security there and she knows that she’s safe and gonna be looked after. 

—Sophie Turner

summary: Except, you know, the northern lords basically offered Sansa the crown. That was an act of treason, they weren't simply...
question: Except, you know, the northern lords basically offered Sansa the crown. That was an act of treason, they weren't simply "complaining".
answer: Oh wow, this is fast. Okay as far as I know, act of treasons are, oathbreaking, regicide, and rebellion and in that scene I didn’t see any of NL take arms against jon, or commit any form of rebellion, all they did was just saying that maybe they should choose sansa to rule, sansa didn’t usurped jon and named herself as queen, they didn’t renounce jon’s claim as a king, they literally just complaining, that’s all

reblog.comment: Oh wow, this is fast. summary: Word of the Day: tongue-in-cheek
title: Word of the Day: tongue-in-cheek
body:
Entry 1 of 2

tongue-in-cheek (adjective)

: characterized by insincerity, irony, or whimsical exaggeration

Entry 2 of 2 

tongue-in-cheek (adverb)

: with insincerity, irony, or whimsical exaggeration

Examples of tongue-in-cheek used in a sentence (adverb)

// The whole interview was done tongue in cheek.

summary:
In the new Kit interview about Jon Snow’s journey, he repeatedly calls Daenerys “Dany.” 
In the Season 7 interview/promo stuff,...
body:
In the new Kit interview about Jon Snow’s journey, he repeatedly calls Daenerys “Dany.”

In the Season 7 interview/promo stuff, he only ever called her Daenerys.

Based on hair length and Emilia’s hair, these interviews were done during the filming of Season 8.

Conclusion: Jon calls Daenerys “Dany” throughout Season 8. 😍🥰💕❤️
